did.abstract: The Donald S. Daughtry Papers consist of material compiled between 1965-2010 by the Reverend Donald S. Daughtry in his capacity as a participant in civil rights and anti-war causes. The papers include correspondence to allies and opponents, drafts of sermons addressing pacificist and humanist topics, and manuscripts of Daughtry's politically-oriented poetic work.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Reverend Donald S. Daughtry in 2015. The accession numbers related to this gift are 2015.019 and 2015.058.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material from accrual 2015.058 has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Donald S. Daughtry (1930-) was a pastor active in the American civil rights and anti-war movements in the late 20th Century. Born into a conservative Southern Baptist family in Charleston, SC, he joined the Air Force, served as a chaplain for the Pacific Missile Range, and founded the Marshall Islands Journal, the first newspaper in the Marshall Islands. Beginning in 1967, Daughtry was associate pastor of First Congregational Church in Atlanta, GA and pursued an active role in the civil rights movement. A friend of Martin Luther King, Sr., Daughtry was introduced to Martin Luther King Jr. and, after MLK's assassination, met regularly with religious leaders in Coretta Scott King's house. Daughtry settled in Florida after serving in churches in Seattle and Hawaii and began a period of concerted activism. He became a poet, a leader of the nuclear-freeze movement, an advocate of US-Soviet friendship, a facilitator of increased ties between Jewish and Christian religious leaders.

processinfo.head: Processing note
processinfo.p: Materials from accrual 2015.058 were moved into archival housing at the time of accessioning, and a collection finding aid was created to describe these materials. No physical processing or arrangement was performed at this time.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Material from a 2015 accrual includes personal correspondence, drafts of articles and sermons addressing such topics as civil rights, poverty and capitalism, charity, feminism, and universal humanism, Daughtry's poetic manuscripts, and a large quantity of letters addressed to prominent world leaders (circa 1980-2008).
